previous: >>69026017

>Advice for new runners
- Try to keep your cadence high (at or around 180 steps per minute)
- Try to keep your heartrate in Zone1/2 (around an average of 55-65% of your max. heart rate)
- Build up speed and mileage SLOOOOWLY (start with 15 minutes, increase time/mileage by 10% per week)
- Yes, it will feel like you're going slow, you are; don't worry about setting good times for at least a couple months
- If you start to feel pain anywhere, stop and rest, then run a shorter distance next time or walk
- Don't worry about form, the human body knows how to run, just do what comes naturally
- If you can comfortably run 6 miles at one time, start thinking about what your goal race is, and look for a training routine for that race.

threads.com:
Any country where wheat, rye, corn, basedbeans, (really any cereal or grain) and even coffee and chocolate are grown or stored is affected. Zearalenone (ZEA) fungus forms when any of these items gets wet, usually in the field before harvesting, and produces a mycotoxin that behaves as an estrogen and causes reproductive harm. Nothing can be done about it because contamination happens before harvest in the open environment.

Legal limits for this mycotoxin in food supply:
>Russia 1000mcg/kg
>EU 20-350mcg/kg
>US no limit

https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3968378/

"The maximum tolerated levels of ZEA for human consumption have been established as 20 μg/kg in food intended for babies and infants, 50 μg/kg in maize-based snacks and breakfast cereals, and 200 μg/kg in unprocessed maize and certain maize products [14]. However, there are reliable case reports of early puberty in girls chronically exposed to ZEA in various regions of the world"

threads.name: Anonymous
threads.com:
Well fed bunny edition

>Who is /fat/ for?
For ducks and nuns who are working towards a better physique through meaningful hard-work, strategy, and dedication. This is not QTDDTOT, stick to questions on fat loss. Post height and weight when asking for advice.
Join our Fatty Contest: https://www.fattycontest.com/

>What do I do first?
1. Read https://physiqonomics.com/fat-loss/
2. Calculate your Body Fat Percentage: https://fitness.bizcalcs.com/Calculator.asp?Calc=Body-Fat-Navy
3. Calculate your TDEE: https://www.sailrabbit.com/bmr/
Remember to use bodyfat% and use Katch-McArdle Formula with sedentary settings or your TDEE will be too high.
4. Plan your weight loss: https://www.losertown.org/eats/cal.php
5. Track your nutrition with MyFitnessPal (better for packaged food), Cronometer (better for generic food/macros) or LoseIt (great for both).

>Now what?
Count calories, all of them.
Eat about 500-1000 less calories than your TDEE.
Buy scales, be accurate.
Learn to cook. Try to stick to lean protein and green vegetables.
Eat a lot of protein. 0.72g per lb of goal lean body mass.
Doing cardio, even just walking, will improve your health. There is no such thing as a healthy fat heart, but you can offset the risks.
Lifting weights will keep and gain muscle mass and burn fat much quicker. No lifting results in the body burning away muscle AND fat.
Drink more water.
Read the /fit/ sticky: https://liamrosen.com/fitness.html

>DON'T
Eat refined sugars, they're terrible for you regardless of calories.
Eat processed foods.
Drink your calories (alcohol, soda, starbucks).
Freak out over a weight loss stall. Plateaus can last up to three weeks.
"Reward" yourself. Cheat days cheat only yourself.

>Other resources:
Loose skin, gyno & stretch marks: https://weight-loss-side-effects.netlify.app/
Reddit wiki: https://www.reddit.com/r/loseit/wiki/faq

last_replies.com:
>>69051361
>Is this actually all you need?
no, you need cover all basic movement patterns:
>upper body vertical push, e.g. OHP
>upper body horizontal push, e.g. bench press
>vertical pull, e.g. pull-ups
>horizontal pull, e.g. rows
>lower body push, e.g. squat
>lower body pull, e.g. deadlift
>rotary motion, e.g. russian twists, if you don't do any unilateral exercises
>abs, e.g. hanging leg raises, if you don't do any compounds that heavily target the abs, like pullups with raised legs, squats and deadlifts don't count
>calves if you don't do any athletic movements that target them
it's literally the minimum to not end up with muscular imbalances. my squat was stalling forever, turned out it was because my non-existent calves of all things, and went up as soon as I started training them regularly. the same happened for deadlift and abs
curls are probably needed too, pull exercises don't hit the biceps enough for most people

A basic property of the heart muscle is that when it beats more frequently, it beats more strongly. This is called the staircase effect, from the way a tracing of its motion rises, beat by beat, as the rate of stimulation is increased. This is a logical way to behave, but sometimes it fails to occur: In shock, and in heart failure, the pulse rate increases, without increasing the volume of blood pumped in each contraction.
